Hey, that's useful!  Thanks Mike...

Rob Manning

--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> r_m_manning@h... wrote:
> 
> > At my company we deploy patch jars (i.e. jars with only the class
> > files that correspond to source code that has changed) to our
> > customers.  We've been burned in doing this but it's offered some
> > useful learning experiences :)  The particular error you are seeing
> > comes from compiling against a JUnit jar in which the Assert class
> > contains an assert method that wasn't declared static.  But when you
> > run you're testcase you're using a different version of the JUnit.jar
> > in which the Assert class' assert method *is* declared static.  The
> > solution is to make sure that the JUnit.jar file in the CLASSPATH is
> > exactly the same for both compiling and running your testcase.
> >
> 
> To help identify which class is being used first according to the
CLASSPATH,
> you can use JWhich.
> 
> Example:
> 
>     > java JWhich junit.framework.Assert
> 
>        Class 'junit.framework.Assert' found in
>        'file:/C:/junit/junit.jar!/junit/framework/Assert.class'
> 
> JWhich is freely available at
http://www.clarkware.com/software/jwhich.zip
> 
> Hope this helps.
> 
> Mike
> 
> --
> Mike Clark
> Clarkware Consulting, Inc.
> http://www.clarkware.com
